message_1:
Consider a smooth projective curve $C$ of genus $3$ defined over the field $\mathbb{Q}$. Let $\mathcal{O}_C$ be the structure sheaf of $C$ and $\mathcal{K}_C$ be the canonical sheaf of $C$. Suppose we have an exact sequence of sheaves on $C$:

$$0\longrightarrow \mathcal{O}_C(-P)\longrightarrow\mathcal{O}_C\longrightarrow\mathcal{O}_P\longrightarrow 0,$$

where $P$ is a point on $C$. Compute the dimension of $H^1(C,\mathcal{K}_C(-P))$.
message_2:
To compute the dimension of $H^1(C, \mathcal{K}_C(-P))$, we will use the long exact sequence in cohomology associated to the given short exact sequence of sheaves. First, we tensor the given short exact sequence with $\mathcal{K}_C$:

$$0 \longrightarrow \mathcal{K}_C \otimes \mathcal{O}_C(-P) \longrightarrow \mathcal{K}_C \otimes \mathcal{O}_C \longrightarrow \mathcal{K}_C \otimes \mathcal{O}_P \longrightarrow 0.$$

Since $\mathcal{K}_C \otimes \mathcal{O}_C \cong \mathcal{K}_C$ and $\mathcal{K}_C \otimes \mathcal{O}_C(-P) \cong \mathcal{K}_C(-P)$, we have the following short exact sequence:

$$0 \longrightarrow \mathcal{K}_C(-P) \longrightarrow \mathcal{K}_C \longrightarrow \mathcal{K}_C \otimes \mathcal{O}_P \longrightarrow 0.$$

Now we can apply the long exact sequence in cohomology:

$$\cdots \longrightarrow H^0(C, \mathcal{K}_C) \longrightarrow H^0(C, \mathcal{K}_C \otimes \mathcal{O}_P) \longrightarrow H^1(C, \mathcal{K}_C(-P)) \longrightarrow H^1(C, \mathcal{K}_C) \longrightarrow \cdots$$

We know that $H^0(C, \mathcal{K}_C)$ has dimension $g = 3$ (the genus of the curve) and $H^1(C, \mathcal{K}_C)$ has dimension $0$ (by Serre duality). To compute the dimension of $H^0(C, \mathcal{K}_C \otimes \mathcal{O}_P)$, we note that $\mathcal{K}_C \otimes \mathcal{O}_P \cong \mathcal{K}_C|_P$, which is a skyscraper sheaf supported at $P$. Since $P$ is a point, we have $\dim H^0(C, \mathcal{K}_C \otimes \mathcal{O}_P) = 1$.

Now we can compute the dimension of $H^1(C, \mathcal{K}_C(-P))$ using the long exact sequence:

$$\dim H^1(C, \mathcal{K}_C(-P)) = \dim H^1(C, \mathcal{K}_C) + \dim H^0(C, \mathcal{K}_C) - \dim H^0(C, \mathcal{K}_C \otimes \mathcal{O}_P) = 0 + 3 - 1 = 2.$$

Thus, the dimension of $H^1(C, \mathcal{K}_C(-P))$ is $2$.
